title: HTML Links (Hyperlinks)
description: Links are one of the core building blocks of the web. They let users navigate between pages, websites, or even trigger actions like sending an email. When you hover over a link, your cursor changes into a hand icon — indicating that it’s clickable. Note: A link can be more than just text. It can be an image, a button, or even a block element!
sub1_desc: The <a> tag defines a hyperlink and uses the href attribute to specify the destination: <a href="url">link text</a> Clicking on the link text takes the user to the provided URL.
note1: Note: The visible text (inside <a>) is what users will click on.
sub2_desc:
By default, browsers render links as follows:
  • Unvisited links — blue and underlined
  • Visited links — purple and underlined
  • Active links — red and underlined
You can customize their appearance using CSS.
sub3_desc:
By default, a link opens in the same browser tab. You can change this behavior using the target attribute:
  • _self – opens in the same tab (default)
  • _blank – opens in a new tab
  • _parent – opens in the parent frame
  • _top – opens in the full body of the window
example2: Open Google in a new tab
tip1: Tip: When using target="_blank", always include rel="noopener noreferrer" for better security.
sub4_desc:
There are two types of URLs you can use in links:
  • Absolute URL: full web address, including https://
  • Relative URL: path relative to the current page or website root

summary:
• Use the <a> element to create hyperlinks.
  • Use the href attribute to define the destination address.
  • Use target="_blank" to open links in a new tab (with rel="noopener noreferrer").
  • Use mailto: to create email links.
  • Links can be text, images, or even buttons styled with CSS.
